title: Printed Blog: Sustainable solution or oxymoron?
body:
When I first read about The Printed Blog, which bills itself as "the world's first daily newspaper comprised entirely of blogs and other user generated content," I thought that the poly-branded business model I've been predicting had finally arrived. Aggregating posts from many different bloggers in a compact print format that's customizable by geographical region seemed to be a unique business model. It fit my idea of a blended portfolio of organizational and personal brands, the old AOL "family of brands" gambit punched up for the 21st century. That's what I see as the winning strategy for newspapers: allowing readers to assemble their own branded collection of content, interacting under the corporate brand, but modifying it according to personal taste.

I also thought The Printed Blog represented the greening of an industry that is ipso facto the antithesis of sustainability. Why print all the news, even in the age of recycling, if you only want to read some of it? After a flawed first attempt (when printing, be sure to select "Scale down larger pages"), I ran off my copy and put it on the stack of reading I optimistically maintain in one corner of my desk. I haven't finished it, but I like the fact that The Printed Blog encapsulates an online experience in a form I can take with me when I leave the house. That's still the value proposition: paper is portable. So are digital devices, but they don't fit the use case, the social consumption model that says you might want to sit in a coffee shop and read something other than a screen.

The Printed Blog is a brand, like any other 'zine in hard copy or online.ï¿½  It's currently available in pdf format. Should it also be online, in its own digital layout? Perhaps. Those of us who kill trees for a living would doubtlessly feel we were doing our part, but I guess the whole point is to sell the hard copy, though it's given away free at the moment. The New York Times thinks that's cute. Yeah, about as cute as the Web was in the beginning, and look what happened.

Is this the blended brand that lights the way for newspapers? Too early to tell, but it's worth watching.
